message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint suggest a ruptured flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx usually involves joint laxity or bony tenderness. Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath would cause pain with passive extension of the finger. Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would cause inability to extend the finger.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the inability to flex at the distal interphalangeal joint suggest a rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx would result in instability of the joint and joint laxity, which is not present in this patient. Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath would result in pain with movement of the finger, which is not present in this patient. Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would result in inability to extend the finger, which is not present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the inability to flex at the DIP joint suggest rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. Closed fractures usually present with tenderness and swelling, but not necessarily an inability to flex. Inflammation of the FDP tendon sheath presents with pain, swelling, and pain with passive or active finger movement. Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon presents with inability to fully extend the finger, not an inability to flex at the DIP joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. The injury occurred during football when the finger got caught in the jersey and was forcefully pulled away, which is a mechanism commonly associated with this injury. The inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint also supports this diagnosis. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx or slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would not cause the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint. Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath may cause pain and swelling in the affected finger, but it would not result in the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint with the inability to flex the finger, suggesting a rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx would have visible signs of deformity, but there is no mention of this in the scenario. Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath would involve pain with tendon movement but not necessarily a loss of ability to flex. Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would lead to a mallet finger deformity with inability to extend the fingertip.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury pattern described suggests a rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. The inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint is a key finding. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx or inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath would not result in this specific pattern of findings. Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would result in a mallet finger, not the inability to flex at the distal interphalangeal joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the inability to flex at the distal interphalangeal joint suggest a rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx would cause pain and swelling without the inability to flex, while inflammation of the FDP tendon sheath would result in pain with some limitation of movement. Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would cause an inability to extend the finger rather than flex it.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint suggest rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. Closed fracture and slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would have different presentations. Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath would present with pain and swelling in the palm or fingers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to flex his right ring finger at the distal interphalangeal joint after experiencing forceful pull is suggestive of a rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx would show up on an x-ray, and there is no joint laxity or inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath. The slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon would cause a mallet finger, where the person can't extend the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury suggests a rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion. The inability to flex the DIP joint of the affected finger is a common presentation of this injury. Closed fracture of the distal phalanx can also present with pain and swelling, but it will not affect finger movement like in this case. Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath, also known as trigger finger, can cause pain and limited finger movement but typically affects the proximal interphalangeal joint. Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon, also known as mallet finger, presents with an inability to extend the DIP joint of the affected finger.
